name: K2-3
scenarioDescription:
The K2-3 Exoplanetary System


Overview

K2-3 is a star with 0.6 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.56 times its radius. It is located NaN light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 1 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

K2-3 is known to have undefined exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the K2-3 system


K2-3 b

K2-3 b was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-3 b is 6.484019999999999 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-3 b is 1.98 that of Earth. At 6.484019999999999 Earth masses, K2-3 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


K2-3 c

K2-3 c was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-3 c is 2.14014 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-3 c is 1.56 that of Earth. At 2.14014 Earth masses, K2-3 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


K2-3 d

K2-3 d was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.21 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of K2-3 d is 2.80158 times the mass of Earth. The radius of K2-3 d is 1.53 that of Earth. At 2.80158 Earth masses, K2-3 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
